required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Healthy Lifestyles for Mentally Ill People Who Have Experienced Weight Gain From Their Antipsychotic Medications - 2
clinical_study.official_title: Management of Antipsychotic Medication Associated Obesity - 2

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: This program aims to help Veterans who take antipsychotic medications lose weight. We use a program based on the American Diabetes Association's "Diabetes Prevention Program," and we have modified it to fit the lifestyles of people with mental illness. All participants are educated about nutrition and cutting down fat intake, how and when to exercise, and the causes of diabetes and how to prevent it. Participants must be Veterans who live within one hour of the Long Beach, West Los Angeles, Sepulveda, or West Los Angeles VA hospitals.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Weight Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
primary_outcome.description: Participants' weight was measured at each visit by study personnel using hospital scales, and the study groups' average weight changes per week were compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Waist Circumference Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
primary_outcome.description: Participants' waist circumference was measured at each visit by study personnel using a measuring tape, and the study groups' average waist circumference changes per week were compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Body Mass Index (BMI) Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
primary_outcome.description: Study personnel calculated each participant's BMI at each visit using their weight measurement taken at that visit and their height measurement taken at baseline. The study groups' average BMI changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Serum Insulin Level Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 5 observations per person, at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Results obtained through VA facility's Outpatient Lab. The study groups' average serum level changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Triglycerides Level Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 5 observations per person, at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Results obtained through VA facility's Outpatient Lab. The study groups' average blood level changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Cholesterol Level Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 5 observations per person, at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Results obtained through VA facility's Outpatient Lab. The study groups' average blood level changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) Cholesterol Level Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 5 observations per person, at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Results obtained through VA facility's Outpatient Lab. The study groups' average blood level changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Health Knowledge Quiz Mean Total Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person,at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Quiz of information covered during Lifestyle Balance classes, score range 0 - 30, worst to best. The study groups' average score changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Mean Total Calories Consumed Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
primary_outcome.description: Caloric intake assessed by dietitians using participant-recorded weekly food and exercise journals. The study groups' average change in total calories consumed per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Mean Empty Calories Consumed Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
primary_outcome.description: Caloric intake assessed by dietitians using participant-recorded weekly food and exercise journals. The study groups' average change in empty calories consumed per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Mean Total Exercise Time Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
primary_outcome.description: Minutes exercised assessed by dietitians using participant-recorded weekly food and exercise journals. The study groups' average change in total minutes exercised per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean University Rhode Island Change Assessment Scale (URICA) Total Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported survey of respondents' feelings about changing their weight problem. Total score is also called the Readiness Score, ranging from -2 to +14 (worse to better), calculated by subtracting the mean from the precontemplation responses from the summation of the means of responses to contemplation, action, and the struggling to maintain items.

primary_outcome.measure: WHO Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) Mean Domain 1 Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported survey of quality of life as related to respondents' physical health, score range 7-35, worst to best. The study groups' average subscore changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: WHO Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) Mean Domain 2 Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported survey of quality of life as related to respondents' psychological health, score range 6-30, worst to best. The study groups' average subscore changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: WHO Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) Mean Domain 3 Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported survey of quality of life as related to respondents' social relationships, score range 3-15, worst to best. The study groups' average subscore changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: WHO Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) Mean Domain 4 Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported survey of quality of life as related to respondents' environment, score range 8-40, worst to best. The study groups' average subscore changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) Mean Total Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Clinician-assessed symptom survey, score range 18 - 126, best to worst. The study groups' average score changes per week were then compared.

primary_outcome.measure: Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI) Mean Total Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported symptom survey, score range 0 - 63, best to worst. The study groups' average score changes per week were then compared.

arm_group.description: Control group with time-matched study visits
Weight management group education and individual counseling
Participants originally randomized to Usual Care, allowed to change over to Lifestyle Balance at month 6 per their request.

intervention.description: Patients assigned to the behavioral weight loss program (Lifestyle Balance Program) will do the following: -Meet with their psychiatrist and a nutritionist who will go over diet recommendations with the patient - Be given a 7% weight loss goal - Be assisted in obtaining a 500 calorie reduction per day -Exercise for at least 30 min/day, at least 5 days a week - Maintain weekly food and exercise diaries -Be quizzed on their knowledge of healthy eating habits and nutrition

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Must be a Veteran
- Diagnosis of psychotic disorders, schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder and bipolar illness
- Age 18-70
- Clinically determined to require ongoing treatment with Second Generation Antipsychotics (SGA) such as olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine, ziprasidone, aripiprazole, clozapine
- Experienced weight gain since treatment with SGA's
- Inpatient or outpatient at Long Beach, West Los Angeles, Sepulveda, or Downtown VA
- Competent to sign informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Have recently been diagnosed with schizophrenia (less than 1 year)
- Are pregnant or breast feeding a baby
- Have a medically unstable condition

overall_official.affiliation: VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System, West Los Angeles, CA

facility.name: VA Long Beach Healthcare System, Long Beach, CA
VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System, Sepulveda, CA
VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System, West Los Angeles, CA

reference.citation: Kwan CL, Gelberg HA, Rosen JA, Chamberlin V, Shah C, Nguyen C, Pierre JM, Erickson ZD, Mena SJ, King M Jr, Arnold I, Baker MR, Meyer HB, Ames D. Nutritional counseling for adults with severe mental illness: key lessons learned. J Acad Nutr Diet. 2014 Mar;114(3):369-74. doi: 10.1016/j.jand.2013.12.005.

Gelberg HA, Kwan CL, Mena SJ, Erickson ZD, Baker MR, Chamberlin V, Nguyen C, Rosen JA, Shah C, Ames D. Meal replacements as a weight loss tool in a population with severe mental illness. Eat Behav. 2015 Dec;19:61-4. doi: 10.1016/j.eatbeh.2015.06.009. Epub 2015 Jul 2.

results_reference.citation: Erickson ZD, Kwan CL, Gelberg HA, Arnold IY, Chamberlin V, Rosen JA, Shah C, Nguyen CT, Hellemann G, Aragaki DR, Kunkel CF, Lewis MM, Sachinvala N, Sonza PA, Pierre JM, Ames D. A Randomized, Controlled Multisite Study of Behavioral Interventions for Veterans with Mental Illness and Antipsychotic Medication-Associated Obesity. J Gen Intern Med. 2017 Apr;32(Suppl 1):32-39. doi: 10.1007/s11606-016-3960-3.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment from outpatient mental health clinics at four southern California VA facilities occurred from September 2010 through March 2014.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were terminated from study prior to randomization to study groups due to screen failure or withdrawal from study during the baseline assessment period.

group.title: Usual Care
group.description: Control group with time-matched study visits

group.title: Lifestyle Balance
group.description: Weight management group education and individual counseling Patients randomized to the Lifestyle Balance Program will do the following: Meet with their psychiatrist and a nutritionist who will go over diet recommendations with the patient Be given a 7% weight loss goal Be assisted in obtaining a 500 calorie reduction per day Exercise for at least 30 min/day, at least 5 days a week Maintain weekly food and exercise diaries Be quizzed on their knowledge of healthy eating habits and nutrition

group.title: Usual Care Then Lifestyle Balance
group.description: Participants originally randomized to Usual Care, allowed to change over to Lifestyle Balance at month 6 per their request. Patients randomized to the Lifestyle Balance Program will do the following: Meet with their psychiatrist and a nutritionist who will go over diet recommendations with the patient Be given a 7% weight loss goal Be assisted in obtaining a 500 calorie reduction per day Exercise for at least 30 min/day, at least 5 days a week Maintain weekly food and exercise diaries Be quizzed on their knowledge of healthy eating habits and nutrition

group.title: Usual Care
group.description: Control group with time-matched study visits Includes 17 participants who would later join “Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance” group to receive the Lifestyle Balance intervention.

group.title: Lifestyle Balance
group.description: Weight management group education and individual counseling Lifestyle Balance: Patients assigned to the behavioral weight loss program (Lifestyle Balance Program) will do the following: -Meet with their psychiatrist and a nutritionist who will go over diet recommendations with the patient - Be given a 7% weight loss goal - Be assisted in obtaining a 500 calorie reduction per day -Exercise for at least 30 min/day, at least 5 days a week - Maintain weekly food and exercise diaries -Be quizzed on their knowledge of healthy eating habits and nutrition

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

Age
Sex: Female, Male
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Region of Enrollment
Living Situation
measure.description: Self-selected description of living situation.
measure.population: One Usual Care subject declined to respond.

measure.title: Education
measure.description: Self-selected description of highest education level reached.
measure.population: One Usual Care subject declined to respond.

measure.title: Marital Status
Job Status
measure.description: Self-selected description of employment situation. Unpaid=homemaker, student, volunteer; None=retired, disabled.
measure.population: One Usual Care and one Lifestyle Balance subject declined to respond.

measure.title: Diagnosis
measure.description: Based on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual-IV criteria

measure.title: Antipsychotic (Weight Gain Risk)
measure.description: Seven Usual Care and seven Lifestyle Balance participants were documented to be on Multiple antipsychotic medications. They are reported in the "Multiple" category, and also contribute to the tally of each of those antipsychotic medications.

measure.title: Length of Illness
Age at Onset

outcome.title: Mean Weight Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
outcome.description: Participants' weight was measured at each visit by study personnel using hospital scales, and the study groups' average weight changes per week were compared.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 19 observations per person, weekly for the first 2 months, then monthly for 10 months.
outcome.population: Analysis excludes 17 Usual Care participants who would later self-select (breaking their randomization) to join “Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance” group to receive the Lifestyle Balance intervention.

group.title: Lifestyle Balance
group.description: Weight management group education and individual counseling to review goals and diet and exercise journals.

measure.title: WHO Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) Mean Domain 3 Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
measure.description: Self-reported survey of quality of life as related to respondents' social relationships, score range 3-15, worst to best. The study groups' average subscore changes per week were then compared.
measure.population: Analysis excludes 17 Usual Care participants who would later self-select (breaking their randomization) to join “Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance” group to receive the Lifestyle Balance intervention.
measure.units: Scores on a scale per week

outcome.title: WHO Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) Mean Domain 4 Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
outcome.description: Self-reported survey of quality of life as related to respondents' environment, score range 8-40, worst to best. The study groups' average subscore changes per week were then compared.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
outcome.population: Analysis excludes 17 Usual Care participants who would later self-select (breaking their randomization) to join “Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance” group to receive the Lifestyle Balance intervention.

group.title: Usual Care
group.description: Control group with time-matched study visits.

outcome.title: Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) Mean Total Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
outcome.description: Clinician-assessed symptom survey, score range 18 - 126, best to worst. The study groups' average score changes per week were then compared.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
outcome.population: Analysis excludes 17 Usual Care participants who would later self-select (breaking their randomization) to join “Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance” group to receive the Lifestyle Balance intervention.

outcome.title: Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI) Mean Total Score Change Per Week From Baseline to Termination
outcome.description: Self-reported symptom survey, score range 0 - 63, best to worst. The study groups' average score changes per week were then compared.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 4 observations per person, at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.
outcome.population: Analysis excludes 17 Usual Care participants who would later self-select (breaking their randomization) to join “Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance” group to receive the Lifestyle Balance intervention.

reported_events.time_frame: During 52-week period from participant randomization to termination.
reported_events.desc: 17 participants in "Usual Care then Lifestyle Balance" group are included in both Usual Care and Lifestyle Balance arms, as they were exposed to both interventions. Events for these participants are reported per intervention, tallied under the intervention they were in at the time the event occurred.

group.title: Usual Care
group.description: Control group with time-matched study visits

group.title: Lifestyle Balance
group.description: Weight management group education and individual counseling Lifestyle Balance: Patients assigned to the behavioral weight loss program (Lifestyle Balance Program) will do the following: -Meet with their psychiatrist and a nutritionist who will go over diet recommendations with the patient - Be given a 7% weight loss goal - Be assisted in obtaining a 500 calorie reduction per day -Exercise for at least 30 min/day, at least 5 days a week - Maintain weekly food and exercise diaries -Be quizzed on their knowledge of healthy eating habits and nutrition

event.sub_title: Surgical and medical procedures - Other, specify

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps) - Other, specify
event.description: Positive test for small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: Psychiatry Department at VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System
